revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = The Leadership Challenge | image = The_Leadership_Challenge_5_edition.jpg | caption = | alt = | author = [[James Kouzes]]
[[Barry Z. Posner]] | title_orig = | orig_lang_code = | title_working = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[Leadership]] and [[professional development]] | genre = Business | published = 1987 | media_type = Print | pages = 416 | awards = | isbn = 0470651725 | oclc = | dewey = 658.4/092 | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | wikisource = }} '''''The Leadership Challenge''''' is a book written by [[James Kouzes]] and [[Barry Z. Posner]], published by [[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]]. First published in 1987, the book's fifth edition was released in 2012, in light of its 25th anniversary.{{cite news|last=Gallo|first=Carmine|title=7 Sure-Fire Ways Great Leaders Inspire People To Follow Them|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/carminegallo/2012/09/06/7-sure-fire-ways-great-leaders-inspire-people-to-follow-them/|work=Leadership|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=7 October 2013}} ==Overview== [[Jim Kouzes]] and [[Barry Posner (academic)|Barry Posner]] started developing the idea for ''The Leadership Challenge'' when they were planning to present about leadership at a two-day conference. Academics at [[Santa Clara University]], Kouzes and Posner were set to speak after [[Tom Peters]], who was presenting about successful companies. Kouzes and Posner decided to focus on individual leadership skills. The name for the book came from the concept of the challenges that take place to "make extraordinary things happen", according to Kouzes in 2012. ==="The Five Practices of Exemplary Leadership"=== ''The Leadership Challenge'' uses [[case study|case studies]] to examine "The Five Practices of Exemplary Leadership", as researched and developed by Kouzes and Posner. Their first surveys for the five practices started in 1983, by asking people "What do you do as a leader when you're performing at your personal best?" Over 30 years, they have done thousands of interviews and collected approximately 75,000 written responses. Kouzes and Posner identified five common concepts in their survey, hence the five practices, which are: "Model the Way", "Inspire a Shared Vision", "Challenge the Process", "Enable Others to Act" and "Encourage the Heart".{{cite book|last=Posner|first=James M. Kouzes, Barry Z.|title=The Leadership Challenge Workbook|year=2003|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|location=Hoboken|isbn=0787971782|edition=1st}} Kouzes cites that the last practice, "Encourage the Heart", is the most uncommonly seen in leadership roles. The concept focuses on being sincere, including sincere celebrations devoted to recognizing employee successes. "Model the Way" encourages leaders to behave the same way they encourage others to behave, with their own voice and values.{{cite web|last=Balint|first=Becca|title=Use empathy, courage, honesty to set examples as a leader|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/business/ci_23191621/use-empathy-courage-honesty-set-examples-leader-column|work=Business|publisher=San Jose Mercury News|accessdate=7 October 2013}} "Inspire a Shared Vision" focuses on developing a vision and series of [[goal]]s that everyone at the organization cares about and works towards collectively, with clear understanding. "Challenge the Process" encourages moving "outside the boundaries" to be innovative to make change. "Enable Others to Act" is trust-based, encouraging leaders to create a safe and trusting environment for people to collaborate, experiment, and engage. ===Important leadership traits=== Kouzes and Posner believe that leadership is learned, not something one is born with.{{cite web|last=Evje|first=Brian|title=9 Leadership Myths--& How to Overcome Them|url=http://www.inc.com/brian-evje/nine-leadership-myths-and-how-to-overcome-them.html|work=Lead|publisher=Inc.|accessdate=7 October 2013}} They look at traits seen within [[introvert]] and [[extrovert]] personalities, and examine how they can be developed into leaders by using those skills. For example, extroverts lean towards sharing of their thoughts and ideas with energy to larger groups, when introverts tend to be more quiet and one-on-one in their engagement about ideas to others.{{cite web|last=Brandon|first=John|title=Personality Doesn't Determine Leadership Ability|url=http://www.inc.com/john-brandon/introvert-extrovert-personality-type-leadership.html|publisher=[[Inc. (magazine)|Inc.]]|accessdate=7 October 2013}} A survey featured in the book shows that [[honesty]] is the most respected personality trait that a leader can have.{{cite news|last=Greathouse|first=John|title=John Greathouse: Don’t Wait for the Starting Gun|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/accelerators/2013/07/02/john-greathouse-dont-wait-for-the-starting-gun/|work=The Accelerators|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=7 October 2013}} Three additional traits that leaders around the world share are forward-thinking, inspiration, and competency. The book also looks at work styles and how people function in organizational settings, and how to improve skills like [[Goal|visionising]] based on their personality traits. Kouzes and Posner express an importance in having a "shared vision" for everyone on one's team or at one's company. If a shared vision can be developed and exhibited, staff will be more prone to feeling confident and motivated in their job. Symbolic language like [[metaphor]]s and storytelling are also important components to leadership skills. Kouzes and Posner believe that symbolic language helps in [[persuasion]] and gathering buy-in. Using emotive words and images also helps in inspiring those leaders are leading or hoping to lead. Positive thinking and expression is another key concept in leadership within the book. Positivity can rub off on others around the leader, leading to productivity and satisfaction. Balancing positivity with negativity is important, with positivity a tool that leaders can use to get buy-in from staff for projects and programs. [[Charisma]], honesty, and being emotional are also seen as good signs of leadership. ===Leadership Practices Inventory=== Developed out of the key traits found within "The Five Practices of Exemplary Leadership" is the Leadership Practices Inventory, or LPI, a print and online assessment, which the authors called a "360 assessment tool", which leaders can use to allow staff to be surveyed about specific leaders in their organization.{{cite web|title=Leadership Practices Inventory|url=http://www.leadershipchallenge.com/professionals-section-lpi.aspx|work=Leadership Development Professionals|publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Inc.|accessdate=7 October 2013}} It also provides [[self-assessment]] tools for leaders to learn more about [[behavior]]al tendencies affect their leadership. The tool has been used by [[Cracker Barrel]], the [[United States Treasury Department]], and the [[American Red Cross]]. ==Publication and recognition== The book was first published in 1987. Since then, it has sold over two million copies. It has been translated into 20 languages.{{cite web|last=Baer|first=Drake|title=What leaders do when they're at their best|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3000144/what-leaders-do-when-theyre-their-best|work=Leadership|publisher=Fast Company|accessdate=7 October 2013}} In 2012, the fifth edition of ''The Leadership Challenge'' was released, marking the 25th [[anniversary]] of its publication. When asked about the release of the 5th edition, in light of other leadership development programs that have come into existence, Posner stated that maintaining one's leadership skills was similar to how one might maintain their [[health]] throughout their lives.{{cite web|last=Hill|first=Andrew|title=Financial tomes|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/5d493188-1cfe-11e2-abeb-00144feabdc0.html#axzz2Ag9nXrxb|work=Life & Arts|publisher=Financial Times|accessdate=7 October 2013}} The 5th edition features updated stories and examples for contemporary context. Posner described the 5th edition as being "more prescriptive than descriptive" in its style.{{cite news|last=Frontiera|first=Joe|title=The leadership challenge, 25 years later|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/on-leadership/the-leadership-challenge-25-years-later/2012/08/08/f021862e-e15b-11e1-a25e-15067bb31849_story.html|work=On Leadership|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=7 October 2013|date=27 August 2012}} The book is a core teaching tool in leadership classes at [[St. Catherine University]].{{cite web|last=Aamot|first=Gregg|title=‘Driving Change’ panel: Farm-to-table entrepreneurs influence others by living their mission|url=http://www.minnpost.com/driving-change/2013/01/driving-change-panel-farm-table-entrepreneurs-influence-others-living-their-m|publisher=MinnPost|accessdate=7 October 2013}} Kouzes and Posner have published excerpts and written guest columns featuring ''The Leadership Challenge'' for ''[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]''.{{cite web|last=Kouzes|first=Jim|title=Best practices for developing a dream team|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3000099/best-practices-developing-dream-team|work=Leadership|publisher=Fast Company|accessdate=7 October 2013|author2=Barry Posner }}{{cite web|title=3 Ways to make everyone around you smarter|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3000623/3-ways-make-everyone-around-you-smarter|publisher=Fast Company|accessdate=7 October 2013}} ==Reception== ''[[The Washington Post]]'' describes ''The Leadership Challenge'' as a "business-meets-self help canon."{{cite news|last=Cunningham|first=Lillian|title=Getting to guru: A conversation with leadership expert Jim Kouzes|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/on-leadership/getting-to-guru-a-conversation-with-leadership-expert-jim-kouzes/2012/08/08/47f36dec-e15f-11e1-a25e-15067bb31849_story.html|work=On Leadership|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=7 October 2013|date=23 August 2012}} [[Carmine Gallo]] and [[Tom Gerace]] have cited ''The Leadership Challenge'' as an important book in developing their leadership skills.{{cite news|last=Gaines|first=Patrice|title=First Monday: Gather's Tom Gerace tells what he reads|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/companies/management/monday/2010-08-02-whatiread02_ST_N.htm|work=Money|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=7 October 2013|date=1 August 2010}} [[Verne Harnish]] described the book as "one of the five most important leadership books ever written."{{cite web|last=Harnish|first=Verne|title=#2 Leadership Book; Dream Team; Surprise Finding; Olympic Torch|url=http://verneharnish.typepad.com/growthguy/2012/07/2-leadership-book-dream-team-surprise-finding-olympic-torch.html|work=The Growth Guide|publisher=Verne Harnish|accessdate=7 October 2013}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.leadershipchallenge.com/}} * "[http://www.thestreet.com/video/11733602/tech-ceos-passing-the-leadership-challenge.html Tech CEOs Passing 'The Leadership Challenge']" interview with Barry Posner on [[TheStreet.com]] * "[http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-09-06/news/41803570_1_legacy-answer-santa-clara-university What you are doing right now determines how you will be remembered: Jim Kouzes]" from the ''Economic Times'' {{DEFAULTSORT:Leadership Challenge}} [[Category:John Wiley & Sons books]] [[Category:Personal development]] [[Category:Leadership training]] [[Category:1987 books]]

revision.comment: /* Secondary education */
revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=June 2013}} Education delivered through the [[Medium of instruction|medium]] of the [[Welsh language]] is known as '''Welsh-medium education''' ({{Lang-cy|Addysg Gyfrwng Cymraeg}}). {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Culture of Wales}}Welsh-medium education should be distinguished from the teaching of the Welsh language itself as an academic subject. Welsh as a subject is taught as a first language in Welsh-medium schools. In the majority of English-medium schools, Welsh is taught as a second language and became compulsory for all pupils in Wales at [[Key Stage]]s 1, 2 and 3 (up to age 14) in 1990. In 1999, it became a compulsory subject for Key Stage 4 pupils (GCSE (ages 15 and 16)). Provision of Welsh as a subject in independent (private) schools is less widespread — only a few provide it, and it is taught as a second language. There is no private designated Welsh-medium school in Wales, although one does exist in [[London]], known as the [[London Welsh School]]. Sixteen per cent of pupils in Wales attend Welsh-medium schools, with a further 10 per cent attending schools that are bilingual, dual-medium, or in English with significant Welsh provision.{{Cite web|url=https://statswales.gov.wales/Catalogue/Education-and-Skills/Schools-and-Teachers/Schools-Census/Pupil-Level-Annual-School-Census/Welsh-Language/pupils-by-localauthorityregion-welshmediumtype|title=statswales.gov.wales/Catalogue/Education-and-Skills/Schools-and-Teachers/Schools-Census/Pupil-Level-Annual-School-Census/Welsh-Language/pupils-by-localauthorityregion-welshmediumtype|website=statswales.gov.wales|language=EN|access-date=2017-02-23}} Children wishing to join a Welsh-medium school do not have to speak Welsh to attend if they are young enough to learn the language quickly. [[Ysgol Glan Clwyd]] is an example: although 70 per cent of the pupils attending this school come from homes where English is the main or only language, 95 per cent of pupils finish their education speaking Welsh as proficiently as a native speaker. [[Ysgol Glan Clwyd]] was the first Welsh-medium secondary (comprehensive) school, and opened in [[Rhyl]] in 1956. ==Nursery Education== ''[[Mudiad Ysgolion Meithrin]]'' (Nursery Schools Movement) has established play groups and nurseries throughout Wales which allow children to learn Welsh through [[Language immersion|immersion]]. It is the main Welsh-medium education and care provider in Wales for the early years. There were 11,828 children in cylchoedd meithrin (Mudiad Meithrin playgroups) in 2014-2015, with 22,000 children attending Mudiad Meithrin establishments every week.http://www.comisiynyddygymraeg.cymru/Cymraeg/Rhestr%20Cyhoeddiadau/Adroddiad%205%20Mlynedd%20-%20Gwefan%20-%20Website%20(unigol).pdf {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161011234429/http://www.comisiynyddygymraeg.cymru/Cymraeg/Rhestr%20Cyhoeddiadau/Adroddiad%205%20Mlynedd%20-%20Gwefan%20-%20Website%20%28unigol%29.pdf |date=11 October 2016 }}{{cite web|title=Mudiad Meithrin Annual Report 2014-2015|url=http://www.meithrin.cymru/creo_files/upload/default/adroddiad_blynyddol_20_o_hydref_saesneg_compressed_min.pdf|accessdate=7 September 2017}} The spread of such nurseries has ensured strong demand from parents for Welsh-medium primary schools. The success of ''Mudiad Ysgolion Meithrin'' inspired the ''[[Ikastolak]]'' movement in the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque Country]] and the ''[[Diwan (school)|Diwan]]'' movement in [[Brittany]].{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} ==Primary education== In the primary school sector, the numbers of children in Welsh-medium schools (or in the Welsh-medium stream of dual stream schools) has grown steadily in recent years. Welsh Government statistics show that in 2014, 22.2 per cent of 7 year old learners were assessed through the medium of Welsh first language {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! School year ! Total pupils ! Welsh-Medium
pupils ! Welsh-Medium
as % of total ! % change |- | 2000/2001 | 262,751 | 49,422 | 18.81% | |- | 2001/2002 | 260,151 | 49,687 | 19.10% | +1.5% |- | 2002/2003 | 256,690 | 50,756 | 19.77% | +3.5% |- | 2003/2004 | 252,230 | 51,131 | 20.27% | +2.5% |- | 2004/2005 | 248,328 | 52,792 | 21.26% | +4.9% |- | 2005/2006 | 243,982 | 52,867 | 21.67% | +1.9% |- | 2006/2007 | 240,621 | 54,099 | 22.48% | +3.7% |- | 2007/2008 | 237,917 | 54,895 | 23.07% | +2.6% |- | 2008/2009 | 258,314 | 59,989 | 23.22% | +0.7% |- | 2009/2010 | 257,445 | 60,318 | 23.43% | +0.9% |- | 2010/2011 | 259,189 | 61,073 | 23.56% | +0.6% |- | 2011/2012 | 262,144 | 62,446 | 23.82% | +1.1% |- | 2012/2013 | 264,186 | 63,192 | 23.92% | +0.4% |- | 2013/2014 | 269,421 | 64,366 | 23.89% | -0.1% |- | 2014/2015 | 273,400 | 65,460 | 23.94% | +0.2% |- | 2015/2016 | 276,954 | 66,101 | 23.86% | -0.3% |- |2016/2017 |276,940 |66,612 |24.05% | +0.8% |- |2017/2018 |277,095 |66,189 |23.89% | -0.7% |} ''Information taken from [http://wales.gov.uk/docs/statistics/2008/081127swgs2008ch7ency.xls Schools in Wales]'' (accessed 23 July 2010) ''Update for last three years taken from [http://wales.gov.uk/docs/statistics/2012/120711sdr1082012en.pdf School Census Results, 2012]'' (accessed 17 May 2013) ==Secondary education== The percentage of children in Welsh-medium secondary schools is slightly less than in primary schools, but has also grown, although it appears to have stabilised in the 2010s. Including Middle School pupils from 2012/2013. {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! School year ! Total pupils ! Welsh-Medium
pupils ! Welsh-Medium
as % of total ! % change |- | 2000/2001 | 210,396 | 38,007 | 18.06% | |- | 2001/2002 | 212,024 | 38,817 | 18.31% | +1.4% |- | 2002/2003 | 214,276 | 39,458 | 18.41% | +0.5% |- | 2003/2004 | 215,609 | 40,169 | 18.63% | +1.2% |- | 2004/2005 | 214,626 | 40,221 | 18.74% | +0.6% |- | 2005/2006 | 213,045 | 40,828 | 19.16% | +2.2% |- | 2006/2007 | 210,353 | 40,702 | 19.35% | +1.0% |- | 2007/2008 | 206,936 | 40,756 | 19.69% | +1.8% |- | 2008/2009 | 205,421 | 41,916 | 20.40% | +3.6% |- | 2009/2010 | 203,907 | 43,432 | 21.30% | +4.4% |- | 2010/2011 | 201,230 | 41,764 | 20.75% | -2.7% |- | 2011/2012 | 198,015 | 41,262 | 20.84% | +0.4% |- | 2012/2013 |194,927 |39,326 |20.17% | -3.2% |- | 2013/2014 |189,969 |38,977 |20.52% | +1.7% |- | 2014/2015 |186,784 |38,933 |20.84% | +1.6% |- | 2015/2016 |184,040 |38,858 |21.11% | +1.3% |- | 2016/2017 |183,975 |39,233 |21.32% | +1.0% |- | 2017/2018 |184,371 |40,285 |21.85% | +2.5% |} ''Information taken from [http://wales.gov.uk/docs/statistics/2008/081127swgs2008ch7ency.xls Schools in Wales]'' (accessed 23 July 2010) ''Update for last three years taken from [http://wales.gov.uk/docs/statistics/2012/120711sdr1082012en.pdf School Census Results, 2012]'' (accessed 17 May 2013) == Further education == During 2015/2016, 7.8 per cent of learning activities in the Further Education sector included some element of Welsh, with 0.29 per cent of activities offered through Welsh only. The subjects with the highest number of learning activities with some element of Welsh were Retail and Commercial Enterprise (18.1 per cent); Agriculture, Horticulture and Animal Care (17.7 per cent) and Business, Administration and Law (14.2 per cent).{{Cite web|url=https://statswales.gov.wales/Catalogue/Education-and-Skills/Post-16-Education-and-Training/Further-Education-and-Work-Based-Learning/Learners/Further-Education/learningactivitiesfurthereducationinstitutions-by-subject-mediumofdelivery|title=Learning activities at further education institutions by subject and medium of delivery|website=statswales.gov.wales|language=EN|access-date=2017-07-20}} == Higher education == In 2014/15, the number of higher education students with at least some teaching through the medium of Welsh reached an all-time high with 6,355 students, or 5.1 per cent of all students at Welsh universities.{{Cite web|url=http://gov.wales/statistics-and-research/welsh-higher-education-institutions/?skip=1&lang=en|publisher=Welsh Government |title=Welsh in higher education institutions|website=gov.wales|access-date=2016-10-11}} Of these 6,355 students, 53 per cent were taught entirely through the medium of Welsh and 47 per cent were taught part of their course in Welsh.{{Cite web|url=http://www.assembly.wales/research%20documents/17-015/17-015-web-english.pdf|title=Welsh-medium and bilingual provision in Further and Higher Education|last=Jones|first=Megan|date=July 2017|website=National Assembly for Wales|access-date=20 July 2017}} The [[University of Wales Trinity Saint David|University of Wales, Trinity Saint David]] had both the highest number of students (2,185) and the highest proportion of its students (21 per cent) receiving at least some teaching through the medium of Welsh. [[Wrexham Glyndŵr University|Glyndŵr University]] had both the lowest number (45) and proportion of its students (0.7 per cent) receiving at least some teaching through the medium of Welsh. 10,030 university students in Wales were fluent Welsh speakers in 2015/2016, with a further 10,330 speakers recording themselves as Welsh speakers but not fluent. Of all Universities in Wales, Cardiff University had the highest number of fluent Welsh-speaking students, amounting to 1,755 students. According to the latest data collected in 2015/2016, [[Bangor University]] had the highest percentage of fluent Welsh-speaking students of all Higher Education institutions in Wales: This constituted to 41.7 per cent of all students in the University.{{Cite web|url=https://statswales.gov.wales/Catalogue/Education-and-Skills/Post-16-Education-and-Training/Higher-Education/Welsh-Medium/welshspeakingstudentsinwalesfromwales-by-institution|title=statswales.gov.wales/Catalogue/Education-and-Skills/Post-16-Education-and-Training/Higher-Education/Welsh-Medium/welshspeakingstudentsinwalesfromwales-by-institution|website=statswales.gov.wales|language=EN|access-date=2017-08-29}} ==See also== * [[Education in Wales]] * [[Gaelscoil]]: Irish-medium education ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.bwrdd-yr-iaith.org.uk/cynnwys.php?pID=220&langID=2 Welsh Language Board] * [http://www.mym.co.uk Mudiad Meithrin]: early years Welsh-medium education {{Celtic languages}} [[Category:Education in Wales]] [[Category:Minority schools]] [[Category:Medium of instruction]] [[Category:Welsh language|Education]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox medical person | name = Sir William James Wanless | image = Wanless.jpg | alt = Photo of Sir William James Wanless. | caption = Sir William James Wanless | birth_date = {{Birth date|1865|05|01}} | birth_place = Charleston (now Caledon village, Town of [[Caledon, Ontario|Caledon]]), Ontario, Canada | death_date = {{Death date and age|1933|03|03|1865|05|01}} | death_place = [[Glendale, California]], United States | profession = Surgeon & medical missionary to India |specialism = |research_field = | known_for = Medical Mission in [[Miraj|Miraj, India]] | years_active = 40 Years | education = [[Doctor of Medicine]]
[[New York University School of Medicine]] | work_institutions = Wanless Hospital, Miraj | prizes = [[Knight Bachelor]] of the British Empire | relations = }} '''Sir William James Wanless''', [[Doctor of Medicine|M.D.]], [[F.A.C.S.]] (May 1, 1865 – March 3, 1933) was a Canadian born [[surgeon]], humanitarian and [[American Presbyterian Mission|Presbyterian missionary]] who founded a medical mission in [[Miraj, India]] in 1894 and led it for nearly 40 years.{{cite journal | date = March 25, 1933 | title = Sir William James Wanless | journal = [[The British Medical Journal]] | pmc=2368392 | pmid=20777450 | volume = 1 | issue = 3768 | pages = 544–5 | doi=10.1136/bmj.1.3768.544-d}}{{cite book | author = Lyle L. Vander Werff | title = Christian Mission to Muslims: The Record : Anglican and Reformed Approaches in India and the Near East, 1800–1938 | publisher = William Carey Library | year = 1977 | series = William Carey Library series on Islamic studies | pages = 366 pages | isbn = 9780878083206 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=NuStj-saoQkC&pg=PA74&lpg=PA74}} As part of this mission, Dr. Wanless founded India's first missionary [[medical school]] in 1897, and helped to establish a [[leprosy]] [[sanatorium]] as well as a [[tuberculosis]] hospital, now known as the Wanless Chest Hospital.{{cite book|last=Shavit|first=David |title=The United States in Asia: A Historical Dictionary|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|year=1990|edition=illustrated|pages=514|isbn=9780313267888|url=https://books.google.com/?id=IWdZTaJdc6UC&pg=PA514#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=October 3, 2010}}{{cite book | others = The Gazetteers Department Maharashtra Government | title = Sangli District Gazetteer | editor = DR. ARUNCHANDRA S. PATHAK , Executive Editor and Secretary | publisher = The Gazetteers Department Maharashtra Government | location = Mumbai | year = 1969 | chapter = PUBLIC LIFE AND VOLUNTARY SOCIAL SERVICE ORGANIZATIONS in Sangli Dist. | url = http://www.maharashtra.gov.in/english/gazetteer/SANGLI/public_life_Voluntary%20organisations.html | accessdate = October 3, 2010}} His medical mission turned the once-small village of [[Miraj]] into a major medical center in India. By the time he retired in 1928, the clinic he started had become a 250-bed hospital with several important adjuncts.{{cite book | last = Bull | first = Win Parkings | title = From Medicine Man To Medical Man: A Record of a Century And A Half of Progress in Health and Sanitation as Exemplified By Developments In Peel. | publisher = The Parkings Bull Foundation, George J Mcleod Ltd. | location = Toronto | date = 1934 & 1954 | pages = 366 | isbn= | url = http://www.pinet.on.ca/peeldiglib/Page.asp?PageOrder=332&PubCode=medicine | accessdate = October 3, 2010}} He is considered by many to be India's most famous surgeon of the 19th century, and was known throughout Asia, personally treating princes, [[raja]]hs and [[Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi|Mahatma Gandhi]].Gandhi, M.K. [http://www.mkgandhi.org/letters/chrchmisn/wanless.htm Letter to Sir William Wanless], M.K. Gandhi, June 2, 1931. Retrieved from the MKGandhi.org website, October 6, 2010. In 1928, he was knighted by King [[George V of the United Kingdom|George V]], who appointed him [[Knight Bachelor]] of the British Empire, for treating 1,000,000 patients and restoring sight to 12,000 of them.{{cite news|url=http://archive.scotsman.com/search.cfm?keywords=Sir+William+James+Wanless+&match=boolean&exclusions=&yearFrom=1921&monthFrom=1&dayFrom=1&yearTo=1930&monthTo=12&dayTo=31&sort=Score,desc&entityType=all|title=Dignity of Kinghthood |date=March 14, 1928|publisher=The Scothman |pages=8 |accessdate=October 3, 2010}}{{cite news | title = Dr. William James Wanless, Physician. Knighted by King George and Also Honored by India for Public Services. Missionary For 39 Years. Treated More Than 1,000,000 Patients, Restored Sight of 12,000 and Built Great Hospital | url = http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30B14FD345F17738DDDAF0894DB405B838FF1D3 | quote = Sir William James Wanless, MD, retired Presbyterian Missionary who was knighted by King George V and honored by the British Government in India for his ... |work=New York Times | date = March 6, 1933 | accessdate = 2010-09-30 }}{{cite book|title=The London Gazette|location=London |date=January 2, 1928 as a Supplement to Gazette Issue 33343 published on the 30 December 1927|pages=10 |url=http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/33343/supplements/3|accessdate=3 October 2010}} The Wanless Hospital in Miraj bears his name, and is now a modern 550-bed teaching hospital.{{cite web | url = http://www.wanlesshospital.org/aboutus.htm | title = Wanless Hospital, Miraj Medical center Web | accessdate = October 3, 2010 | location=Miraj India}} == Early life and education == William James Wanless was born on May 1, 1865 to Elizabeth and John Wanless in the then-community of Charleston, Province of Canada (now "Caledon Village", part of [[Caledon, Ontario|Caledon]], [[Ontario]], Canada.) {{cite book | author = David Shavit | title = The United States in Asia: A Historical Dictionary | publisher = [[Greenwood Publishing Group]] | quote = Wanless, William James (1865–1933). Medical missionary, born May 1, 1865, in Charleston, Ontario, Canada. Wanless graduated from University Medical College (New York City). He was a missionary under the Board of Foreign Missions of the ... | year = 1990 | pages = 620 | isbn = 0-313-26788-X | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=IWdZTaJdc6UC&pg=PA514}} He was the sixth of 14 children, including two elder brothers who died in childhood. His father, born in Barrow, Alwinton, Northumberland, England (or possibly Jedboro, Scotland) on December 30, 1832, emigrated to the United States with his family at the age of 17, later emigrating to Canada where he variously became a railroader, a hardware store owner (John Wanless & Sons), and a home heating furnace manufacturer in [[Toronto]] (where [[Wanless Park]] and several streets are named after one of their distant relations, also a John Wanless, a municipal [[Alderman#In Canada|alderman]] and educator). [http://www.wanlessweb.org/TNG/getperson.php?personID=I1349&tree=2 John Wanless, 1832–1911], Wanless Web genealogical website. Retrieved October 3, 2010. {{cite web|url=http://www.peterrussellrealestate.com/4a_custpage_5713.html|title=WANLESS PARK HISTORY|publisher=Chestnut Park Real Estate Ltd., Brokerage|accessdate=October 27, 2010}} During his childhood and adolescence, William was educated in the schools of Charleston, [[Mount Forest, Ontario|Mount Forrest]] and [[Guelph|Guelph, Ontario]]. He graduated from the [[New York University School of Medicine]] in 1889. He married Mary Elizabeth Marshall on September 5, 1889 in Canada, and sailed for India the same year.{{cite book|last=Suryawanshi|first=Rev. S. N. |title=Dr. Sir William J. Wanless Physician Extraordinaire|publisher=Word of Life Publications, 31, Guru Nanaknagar, Pune-42, India |accessdate=November 1, 2010}} Mary gave birth to Ethel at Miraj on Dec 2, 1891. Mary died on August 12, 1906. On December 5, 1907, Dr William married again at [[Kodoli]] to Lillian Emery Havens, who survived him. Lillian gave birth to 3 children: Harold L. Wanless on October 2, 1908, at Miraj; Robert Emery Wanless who became a Pan Am Boeing pilot and Margaret Elizabeth Wanless on August 24, 1917 in Toronto. Lillian later wrote his biography. The Ontario Register. Vol 11, page 99. Wanless was a delegate to the [[1910 World Missionary Conference]] held in [[Edinburgh]], Scotland, and was president of the [[Christian Medical Association of India|Missionary Medical Association of India]] from 1911 to 1928. In 1918 he was made a [[Fellow of the American College of Surgeons]]. He was erroneously reported as dead in 1922; the incorrect report and its subsequent retraction made headlines in the United States. {{cite news | title = Dr. Wanless Not Dead In India As Reported | url = https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courant/access/749146612.html?dids=749146612:749146612&FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:AI&type=historic&date=Jul+13,+1922&author=&pub=Hartford+Courant&desc=DR.+WANLESS+NOT+DEAD+IN+INDIA+AS+REPORTED&pqatl=google | quote = Announcement was made by the Presbyterian hoard of foreign missions today that Dr William Wanless who was reported dead in India on July 7 ... | work = [[Hartford Courant]] | date = July 13, 1922 | accessdate = 2010-09-30 }} == Mission in India == [[File:Cropped Wanless image from 1888, likely at the New York University School of Medicine.jpg|left|thumb|upright=1.2|alt= Photo of William Wanless age 23 at New York|William Wanless, age 23, at the New York University School of Medicine, ca.1888.]] The [[Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church]], of [[Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania]], sent Dr. Wanless to [[India]] in 1889. {{cite book | title = History of the Expansion of Christianity (volume vi) | publisher = Taylor & Francis | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ET8OAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA164}} In 1891, he selected the rustic town of [[Miraj]] in [[Maharashtra State]] for the mission hospital. The Mission was started as a one-room dispensary in a very small rented place at a busy bazaar, and he was assisted by his wife, Mary, a trained nurse. The [[Miraj Senior|Rajah of Miraj]], [[Raja]]h Sir Gangadharrao Ganesh (Bala Saheb) Patwardhan, provided him with land for a hospital which was formally opened in 1894, in a part of the city now known as ''Wanlesswadi''. Kunte, G.J. [http://uqconnect.net/~zzhsoszy/ips/m/mirajsnr.html Miraj Senior (Princely State): Predecessor Rulers and Short History], CHARITRA OF ADYA SANSTHAPAK CHINTAMANRAO APPASAHEB PATWARDHAN, 1972. Retrieved from University of Queensland, Australia, Genealogical Gleanings website, October 6, 2010. {{cite book |title=The Times of India Directory and Year Book Including Who's Who | publisher=Times of India Press | year=1969 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=vsYVAQAAIAAJ | accessdate=October 3, 2010 }} With the establishment of a hospital, the need for higher quality medical care was increasingly felt, and towards that end a School of Nursing was founded in 1897 under the superintendence of Miss Elizabeth Foster. It has since steadily developed into one of the best [[nursing school]]s in Maharashtra. The Mary Wanless Hospital was founded in memory of Wanless's first wife Mary after her death in 1906. Now called the Mary Wanless Hospital / Miraj Medical Centre, it still attracts hundreds of poor and needy patients from across India and abroad. He established the Miraj Christian Medical School in 1907, which later graduated its first group of 17 students, with its only qualified teacher being Wanless himself. In 1917 the medical school was recognized for a Diploma of Licentiate by the College of Physicians and Surgeons of [[Mumbai]] (LCPS), similar to the LRCP of the [[Membership of the Royal College of Surgeons|Royal College of Surgeons]] (MRCS) of England. {{cite book | last=Dawood | first=Yusuf Kodwavwala | title=Nothing But The Truth | publisher = East African Publishers | year = 2002 | pages = 326 | isbn=9789966251220 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1IhxpWR5oU0C&pg=PA55 | accessdate=October 4, 2010}} Wanless established a [[Tuberculosis]] [[Sanatorium]] in 1920. At the time of his retirement in 1928, money was raised by citizens and his friends to erect a new building called the Wanless Tuberculosis Sanatorium, now known as Wanless Chest Hospital. It is one of the premier institutions in the country. The Vail Memorial Cancer Institute, named after Dr. Charles E. Vail who joined Wanless three years later, and the Goheen Psychiatric Clinic were started in 1937 and 1955 respectively. {{cite book | last = Dawood | first = Yusuf Kodwavwala | title = Nothing But The Truth | publisher = East African Publishers | year = 2002 | series = Vitabu Vya Sayari Series | pages = 346 | isbn = 9789966251220 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=1IhxpWR5oU0C&pg=PA55}} The Goheen Clinic was named after Dr. Robert H. H. Goheen, father of [[Robert Francis Goheen]], These facilities have effectively served the purposes for which they were established, that is in providing quality health care to all irrespective of [[caste]], [[creed]], religion or [[Personal finance|financial means]]. {{cite book |author=India Planning Commission | title = Social Welfare in India | publisher = Publications Division, Ministry of Information and Broadcasting | year = 1955 | pages = 850 pages | url = https://books.google.com/?id=BFRpAAAAIAAJ | accessdate=October 7, 2010}} Additionally, Wanless established five outpost stations attached to the hospital, and paid the hospital's staff of 125, living only on his missionary's salary sent by the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church, while donating his personal staff salary to the mission. ===Retirement and legacy=== In 1928, after almost forty years of medical missionary service in India, Wanless retired to live in the United States.{{cite news |title=Ends 40 Years In India. Dr. W.J. Wanless Arrives to Retire From Missionary Work |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1928/03/13/archives/ends-40-years-in-india-dr-wj-wanless-arrives-to-retire-from.html |quote=Dr. William James Wanless, Presbyterian missionary to India, arrived yesterday on the Caronia of the Cunard Line to retire, after more than forty years in the missionary field in Miraj, India. |work=New York Times |date=March 13, 1928 |accessdate=2010-09-30 }} He wrote a book, ''Medicine in India'', on his life as a doctor in India. He died at his home, 1016 Matillja Street, [[Glendale, California]] on March 3, 1933, and was buried at [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park, Glendale|Forest Lawn Memorial Park]] in the same city.{{cite news | title = Dr. William J. Wanless | url = http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50C17F8345F1A7A93C6A91788D85F478385F9 |quote=... who was decorated by the King of England for distinguished service at the Presbyterian Hospital at Miraj India died here today after six weeks illness. |work=New York Times | date = March 4, 1933 | accessdate = 2010-09-30 }}{{cite news | title = Dr. Wanless, of Fame In India, Dies | url = https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/388710931.html?dids=388710931:388710931&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Mar+04,+1933&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=DR.+WANLESS,+OF+FAME+IN+INDIA,+DIES&pqatl=google | quote = Death came today to Dr. William James Wanless, 67 years of age, internationally known physician and author, at his home, 1016 Matillja street, in [[Glendale, California]]. He had been ill for six weeks. |work=Los Angeles Times | date = March 4, 1933 | accessdate = 2010-09-30 }} His wife Lillian died in 1973 at the age of 99 years at their home in Glendale, California. Wanless's son Harold later carried on his father's tradition by studying medicine at the [[University of Toronto]]. Since its inception over 115 years ago his medical mission has grown into an institution consisting of a 550-bed teaching hospital affiliated with India's Government Medical College, a College of Nursing, an Institute of Pharmacy and various paramedical programmes.{{cite web|url=http://www.bmpc.org/Worldwide/Wanless.htm|title=Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church|accessdate=October 3, 2010}}{{cite book |author=Lillian Emery Havens Wanless | title = Wanless of India: Lancet Of The Lord | publisher = W. A. Wilde company | year= 1944 | pages=366 pages | url = https://books.google.com/?id=GWJCAAAAIAAJ&dq=Sir+William+Wanless&q=Ichalkaeanji#search_anchor}} The Wanless Hospital and Wanless Chest Hospital are now located in the township of'' 'Wanlesswadi','' that is 'Wanless town', made notable for its medical institutions. The name was given it by its citizens in that part of India and is recognized by the federal government of India. Wanlesswadi has its own [[Postal Index Number]], 416414, and the [[Indian Railways]] also has a station named 'Wanlesswadi' on its Miraj–Sangli Route, which opened on April 1, 1907 for the use by ill or needy patients from across India and from abroad.{{cite book | publisher=The Gazetteers Department Maharashtra Government | url=http://www.maharashtra.gov.in/english/gazetteer/SANGLI/comm_railways.html | accessdate=October 3, 2010 }} As a secondary and tertiary care centre, Wanless Hospital serves a large part of western [[Maharashtra]] and [[Karnataka|North Karnataka]].{{cite book | last = Montgomery | first = Helen Barrett | title = The King's Highway | publisher = READ BOOKS | year = 2010 | pages = 326 | isbn = 9781444696042 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=CCV3q2ebu0sC&pg=PA78&lpg=PA78 | accessdate = October 3, 2010}} The Wanless Hospital reputedly provides the best possible [[health care|medical care]] to all its patients; an institution for comprehensive and dedicated health care. == Honours == [[File:Knights Bachelor Insignia.png|thumb|right|126px|The badge of a Knight Bachelor]] Dr. Wanless received official honors from Great Britain on three occasions: * He first received the silver [[Kaisar-i-Hind]] (Emperor in India) medal of second class in 1912. * The same order of gold medal of first class in 1920, in recognition of his philanthropic and humanitarian work for India. * The third honor was bestowed upon him on January 2, 1928 by His Majesty, [[George V of the United Kingdom]], was a [[Knight Bachelor|knighthood]] of the [[British Empire]], conferring upon him the degree and honor. {{cite journal|year=1933|title=American Medical Association|journal=Journal of the American Medical Association|publisher=American Medical Association|volume=100 |issue= 14|url=http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/reprint/100/14/1125.pdf|accessdate=October 3, 2010|doi=10.1001/jama.1933.02740140049023}} The [[Aga Khan III|Sultan Mahommed Shah, Aga Khan III]] presented him a silver casket with a farewell address on his retirement. == Publications == A partial list of his writings and works includes: * {{cite journal |last1= Wanless |first1= William James | jstor = 25327510 | title = Cancer of the Uterus | journal = [[BMJ|The British Medical Journal]] | volume = 1 | issue = 3496 | pages = 21–25 [24] | date = January 7, 1928 | doi = 10.1136/bmj.1.3496.21 | id={{subscription}}}} * {{cite journal |last1= Wanless |first1= William James | jstor = 20339668 | title = Intramuscular Injections of Quinine | journal = [[BMJ|The British Medical Journal]] | volume = 1 | issue = 3079 | pages = 21–27 [25–26] | date = January 3, 1920 | doi = 10.1136/bmj.1.3079.21 | id={{subscription}}}} * {{cite journal |last1= Wanless |first1= William James | jstor = 25327509 | title = Iodine, Goitre, and Growth | journal = [[BMJ|The British Medical Journal]] | volume = 1 | issue = 3496 | pages = 21–25 [24] | date = January 7, 1928 | doi = 10.1136/bmj.1.3496.21 | id={{subscription}} }} * {{cite journal |last1= Wanless |first1= William James |title=Medicine in India |journal=Bull N Y Acad Med |volume=6 |issue=2 |pages=105–25 | date=February 1930 |pmid=19311713 |pmc=2095951 |url=}} Origin: delivered before the Section of Historical and Cultural Medicine, November 13, 1929. ;As cited in other works: * Wanless, William James. "The Medical Mission", 1898. * Wanless, William James. "Medical Missions: Facts and Testimonies". * Wanless, William James. "An American Doctor at Work in India", New York, 1932. == Archival Collections == The [[Presbyterian Historical Society]] in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], has [http://www.history.pcusa.org/collections/research-tools/guides-archival-collections/rg-92 Sir W. J.
